title: Theme Shopping - tto123
description: Dit thema valt onder de arrangeerbare leerlijn van de Stercollecties voor Engels voor tweetalig onderwijs, leerjaar 1, 2 en 3. Dit is thema 5 'Shopping'. Het doel van het thema is woorden en basiszinnen begrijpen en toepassen die met winkelen te maken hebben. Het thema omvat de volgende onderwerpen: Buying shoes, Buying presents, Buying clothes en Saving money. In de grammaticaopdrachten wordt er geoefend met some/any, much/many, simple present en present continuous.

items.content:
Welcome to the fifth theme.
This theme is about Shopping.

How are you going to practise?
You are going to practise your writing, reading, listening and speaking skills.

What are you going to do?
You are going to read, listen, speak and write about shops and shopping.
By practising a lot, your English will improve!

Have fun!

You have just started the theme Shopping.
You will find different things to watch, to listen to, to read and of course to do.
There are videos, recordings, pictures, texts and assignments.
There are different types of assignments. Some of them you have to do on your own, others you are doing in a group.

At the end of those group assignments you are going to discuss the answers in your group. Some assignment will be checked by the computer.
First, you are going to do a test to see if you are ready to start this theme.

content.body:
Fill in the right word in the right sentence.
supermarket - buy - repair shop - store - furniture - shop

A shop or is a place where people can go to items that they need or want. People might go to a to buy food, clothes, , jewelry, or many other things. There are loads of shops in the world people can buy there things from.

People might also go to a if something is broken, and they want the shop to fix it. For example, someone might bring a broken bicycle to a bicycle repair shop.
Shops can be anything from large chains to small businesses.

Put the right words in the right sentence.
fruits - meat - grocery stores - supermarket - store

Supermarkets are large that sell a large variety of fresh and packaged food and other consumer or household products. Supermarkets are divided into sections, such as dairy, produce ( and vegetables), , packaged goods, cleaning supplies, and personal hygiene items. The term "" usually refers to a larger than the term "grocery store."

items.content:
In this theme you will focus on the following 'can do' statements.

Listening

  • You can understand words and basic sentences that have something to do with shopping.

Reading

  • You can understand words and basic sentences in a simple story about shopping

Having a conversation

  • You can join a simple conversation when the conversational partner is willing to speak slowly, repeats the sentences, formulates the words and helps you formulate what you're trying to say.
  • You can ask and answer simple questions that have something to do with the theme shopping.

Speaking

  • You can use simple phrases and sentences about the theme shopping.

Writing

  • You can write a short and simple story that has something to do with the theme shopping.

In this theme you are going to:

  • listen to people talking about shopping for different items;
  • read texts about people talking about shopping, online shopping, money in the UK and shopping on a budget;
  • write about shopping, shops and products you can buy in shops;
  • practise conversations in shops and about shopping.

But you don't have to be able to do this right away!
If you take the following steps, you'll find out what you need to know!

Lesson

Title

Activity

1

Buying shoes

Listen to a conversation about buying shoes, read a text about British currency, talk and write about buying shoes.

Grammar: some and any

2

Buying presents

Listen to a conversation about buying a gift, read a text and discuss about opening times of shops. Write an essay about opening times.

Grammar: much and many

3

Buying clothes

Listen to a conversation about opinions about shopping, have a discussion about buying clothes.

Grammar: simple present

4

Saving money

Watch a video and talk about shopping, read a text and write an essay about shopping on a budget.

Grammar: present continuous

In this theme there are four lessons.

Lesson 1

Buying shoes
Lesson 2

Buying presents
Lesson 3

Buying clothes
Lesson 4

Saving money

Vocabulary Shopping

Here you can find the vocabulary lists with sentences (chunks) that accompany this theme.
These lists will also be used in the diagnostic test. Talk to your teacher about when you will learn these lists.

Vocabularylist Shopping A Shopping chunks A
Vocabularylist Shopping B Shopping chunks B
Vocabularylist Shopping C

Tip

There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them.
Click in Wozzol on the red arrow for the options.

You've finished the lessons for the theme Shopping.
Now it is time for the Finishing touch.

Here you will find four extra reading or speaking assignments.
Choose one or two of the assignments and work together with a classmate.
When you are finished, you will make the diagnostic test and fill in the evaluation.

Good luck!

Hold a class survey about shopping. Make sure you include the following questions:

  • Who doesn't like shopping?
  • Who likes shopping slowly and carefully?
  • Who likes shopping with certain people? With whom?
  • Who enjoys shopping alone?

Use the following worksheet if you like.
Make sure you include all your classmate's answers.
You can use Google forms to hold a survey if you like.
Now write a small report on how your class likes shopping.
Were there any differences between boys and girls?

Camden Town is a great place to shop if you like clothes that are a bit unusual.
You'll see some very strange clothes in this video and you'll also find out what a Cyber-Goth is!
Have a look at the video and fill in the worksheet.

Your uncle needs your help!
He wants to make an English brochure for his shop, but his English is not good enough.

  • Think of a type of shop for your uncle.
  • Think of three products you can buy in his shop.
  • Think of a name for the shop.
  • Draw images or look for images on the web.
  • Write down the names and think of a good price!

Before handing the task in, let another classmate correct your brochure.
Test your knowledge. Make the diagnostic test.

content.body:
Fill in in the following sentences: any or some.

  1. There is milk in the fridge.
  2. There isn't beer.
  3. My brother can't speak Chinese.

Fill in in the following sentences: Much or many?

  1. much / many people
  2. much / many thanks
  3. much / many information
  4. much / many love
  5. much / many paper

Fill in the correct form Present simple.

  1. That man (to work) in a shoe factory.
  2. It (to cost) a lot to stay at luxury hotels.
  3. My parents always (to go) to France.

In which sentence the Present Continuous has been used?

  1. The weather has been getting better.
    The weather is getting better.
  2. Is he watching an interesting movie?
    Has he been watching an interesting movie?
  3. Come on, we're waiting for you!
    Come on, we have been waiting for you!

items.value: The weather has been getting better.
Is he watching an interesting movie?
Has he been watching an interesting movie?
Come on, we're waiting for you!
Come on, we have been waiting for you!

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about Types of shops and stores.
After reading the story, answer the questions.

In Great Britain you have different types of shops and stores:

Department Stores
These are large retail stores. They sell a variety of goods and services (e.g. Marks & Spencer, Allders Department Store, Woolworths)

Shopping centre / Mall
Shopping centres have a variety of shops under one roof. They will have an eating area with fast foods and sit down menus, parking area and often a cinema.

Corner shop
A corner shop is a small shop near houses. It has a limited variety of food but often has long opening hours.

Supermarkets
Supermarkets are large self-service shops selling mainly food. Large supermarkets also sell household goods.

Charity shops
Charity shops sell goods (clothes, book and small household items) that have been donated.
The items are usually very cheap and of good quality

Off-Licences
Off-Licence shops sell alcoholic beverages.

Chain stores
Chain stores are a number of retail stores under the same ownership selling the same goods.

  1. Can you park your car in a Shopping Centre?
  2. In what kind of shop will you buy a second-hand dress?

  3. Mention three articles you can buy in a supermarket.

values.value:
1. Yes
  2. Charity shop
  3. Milk, sugar, bread, soap, drinks, eggs, vegetables

content.body:
1. Yes
  2. Charity shop
  3. Milk, sugar, bread, soap, drinks, eggs, vegetables

prompt.body: Read the descriptions and choose the right names of the shops.

content.body: Supermarket
Flowershop
Bookshop
Chemistry
Greengrocer
This shop sells all different kinds of food like sugar, milk, tins of vegetables.
This shop sells most kinds of fruit and vegetables such as apples, bananas, beans and potatoes.
This shop sells books of all kinds including stories and information books.
This is where you go when you want to buy someone a bunch of flowers like roses.
This shop sells bottles of medicine, tablets and things to make you feel better when you are ill.

Below you find some information on Shopping streets.

Shopping streets

The main shopping street in many towns is called the High Street.
You should head for it if you want to go shopping.
A few small shops are owned by local people.
Most are owned by national 'chains' of stores (= winkelketens).
This makes many town centres look the same.
Some towns also have street markets where fresh food and cheap goods can be bought. Away from the town centre, small 'corner' shops provide groceries to local customers.


Below you find a list with some famous international shopping streets.
Do you recognize some names? Name the three streets, which are situated in London.

  • La Rambla
  • Sunset Boulevard
  • Downing Street
  • Abbey Road
  • 42nd Street
  • Broadway
  • Oxford Street
  • Wall Street

prompt.body:
Read the text below and answer the question.

Very special wedding dress

Shopping for a wedding dress can be both challenging and time-consuming, and with wedding season upon us, we thought we'd show you a more creative alternative.

Welcome to the 12th annual toilet paper wedding dress contest. Yes, that's dresses made out of, you guessed it, toilet paper. The annual competition offers a more creative twist to bridal attire and the competitors were flushed with excitement as they made it down to the final 10 out of 1,500 hopefuls.

The designers were only allowed to use toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread to create their masterpieces. The winning dress dubbed "Winter Last" was inspired by the creator's first snowstorm experience.

"I was what happens when you have a winter wedding? It's beautiful. What would you wear? So I definitely developed a snow queen kind of attire."

The creation will be on display at one of Ripley's Believe It or Not global locations and with the ten-thousand-dollar prize, this is one you may want to try at home.

  1. The designers were only allowed to use 5 materials. Mention the 5 materials.
  2. What is the name of the winning dress?
  3. What inspired the creator of the winning dress?
  4. How much money did the winner win?

values.value:
1. Toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread
  2. Winter Last
  3. The creator’s first snowstorm experience.
  4. Ten thousand dollar

content.body:
1. Toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread
  2. Winter Last
  3. The creator's first snowstorm experience.
  4. Ten thousand dollar

items.content:
Can do statements

Take a look at the Can do statements in the introduction - 'Can do'.

  • Are you able to do what you have to do?
  • Which assignment was the best one to learn from?

Analyse your mistakes

What did you learn of the mistakes you made in this theme?
You can learn a lot of your mistakes! What mistakes did you make?

  • I did not learn enough
  • I did not understand the grammar.
  • I made sloppy mistakes.
  • I lost concentration.
  • I used the wrong words, I had to check my vocabulary.

Group work

  • What do you think of working in a group?
  • Did every group member do the same amount of work?

Projects

  • Which project(s) did you choose? Why?
  • What did you think of the project(s)?
